Title: (NU/1589-48) Digital Media Production Support
Description:
We are seeking to appoint a supplier to provide flexible media buying and copy writing support for both digital, out of home and print advertising. 
The supplier will need to be able to work across channels:
•	independently on stand-alone campaign briefs, from single objective campaigns to full funnel approaches
•	provide capacity support for existing campaigns ran by the internal paid media team (eg booking pre-determined 3rd party placements to compliment a wider campaign or managing the international element of a full recruitment cycle paid search campaign)
It is expected the value of each campaign request will be between £5,000 and £100,000 inclusive of all taxes and agency fees. It is estimated there will be at least 6 campaign requests within the contract period.
The supplier may also be required to source and secure conference and award sponsorship opportunities.
The supplier specifically is required to have the ability to provide the following services and experience:
•	Knowledge and experience of booking multi-channel media campaigns for UK and international undergraduate and postgraduate recruitment
•	Knowledge and experience booking international multi-channel media campaigns for brand awareness and research excellence promotion, specifically within the Higher Education sector
•	Knowledge and experience booking campaigns 
•	understanding of key award ceremonies for the Higher Education industry
•	Experience securing award ceremony and/or conference sponsorship opportunities
•	Provide detailed campaign attribution and KPI measurements for all managed campaigns as well as forecast performance
•	Provide full campaign reporting and optimisation as well as a breakdown on hours worked
•	Provide support on creative optimisation and testing inclusive of campaign costs
•	Provide regular insight into industry best practice, trends and future placement opportunities
•	ability to export campaign data and builds at the end of campaigns, or transfer ownership of accounts, where supported by platforms, back in house
•	Provide a single Account Manager for all campaigns
•	Ensure appropriate non-disclosure agreements are in place

Title: QU554 - Supply and install of 'Black Sabbath Bench' cameras for visitor photographs  - AWARD
Description:
The Council requires a supplier to supply and install two cameras (devices) in front of the 'Black Sabbath Bench' on Broad Street to capture photographs of visitors which can be downloaded from a dedicated website managed by Westside Business Improvement District (BID).
      
      Birmingham has been granted funding under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) Welcome Back Fund to support the safe reopening of high streets and other commercial areas. 
      A proportion of this funding is to develop events in a number of urban centre across the city in a covid safe manner which will drive footfall back to high streets and shopping areas.
      
      This contract is available for use for projects funded externally from the Council including Reopening High Streets Safely Fund and Welcome Back Fund which is funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) as part of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) Growth.
      
      This will involve installation of 2 cameras (devices) on Highways Columns opposite the bench.   Technology must allow visitors to place a short message, followed by their name and hometown. 
      
      The facility will need to operate 24 hours a day.
      
      Install must take place by 17 March 2022.
      
      The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. Title: Global Gas Market Future Outlook
Description:
International Gas markets have experienced a significant change within a year, with prices turning from record lows to record highs. The question is whether there are structural shifts that may sustain higher prices, what caused this change, what are the future risks to the market and what impact might they have. This information is needed to help the UK better understand and manage the UK's net zero transition alongside ensuring energy security of supply in a global energy market and the UK's role within a global just energy transition.

This contract is a research project to produce analysis and a report that will benefit BEIS and HMG more widely by increasing the understanding of future gas market risks, enabling BEIS to better prepare for future gas market events and put in place mitigations to protect and prepare UK businesses and consumers. The project will increase the evidence base on gas market risks which will help to structure future BEIS analysis and policy proposals.

Tender documents including full details of the requirement and details for how to apply are attached to this notice. For more information please contact internationalclimateandenergy.procurement@beis.gov.uk

Title: TINSLEY PARK CEMETERY LODGE - EXTERNAL ENVELOPE AND WATER INGRESS REMEDIATION WORKS
Description: The project comprises external envelope and water ingress remediation works including the refurbishment of timber sash windows and doors, re-roofing of pitched slate and flat roof areas, replacement of rainwater goods and the formation of a new channel drainage system. Internally decayed timber elements including door frames, lintels and floor joists will be replaced. Retained finishes will be cleaned down and treated with a fungicidal fluid. To enable the works certain M&E installations will be isolated, disconnected and reinstated. The boiler and heating system will be drained down before the gas and water supplies are capped off. The electric supply will remain connected to ensure the continued working of the intruder alarm. The temporary removal and reinstatement of M&E items, the testing and commissioning of the existing intruder alarm, the electrical testing and condition report and the final connection of the ACO drain channels to the new inspection chamber will be Contractor Designed.

Title: Supported Employment Services for People with Learning Disabilities, Mental Health Needs & Physical Disabilities
Description:
Dorset Council invites bids from suitably qualified and experienced providers to deliver a Supported Employment Service for people with learning disabilities, mental health needs and physical disabilities. Reference: DN548629.
People accessing employment is a key area highlighted in national policies such as Valuing People Now, The Autism Act and The Care Act 2014. Dorset Council commissions a range of services for people (adults) living with learning disabilities and mental health issues and physical disabilities and has ambitious plans to commission a service that supports people in a holistic and strengths-based way, creating a clear pathway to employment and meaningful work placements. Historically, people who use Council services have remained NEET (Not in Education, Employment, or Training), and longer term this is likely to increase their reliance on funded social care services at a time when Council resources are under increasing pressure. 
The service is being commissioned primarily for people supported by the Council who are living with learning disabilities, mental health needs and physical disabilities. However other people with an eligible need may access the service. The Council recognises its duty under the Care Act to ensure employment and volunteering opportunities are available to people with disabilities and other vulnerable adults. The Supported Employment Service will ensure people access and maintain supported employment that is realistic and sustainable; supporting people to achieve economic wellbeing and social inclusion whilst maximising their potential as a person living in Dorset. 
The service will be sourcing and supporting a variety of work and work-related opportunities for people aged 16+ years with Learning Disabilities, Physical Disabilities, Mental Health needs, Autism and other support needs across Dorset. 
Tenderers are advised to read the Procurement Document (ITT) fully before preparing and submitting any bid.

Title: T0277 TETI0035 Current and potential future feedstock availability for low carbon transport fuels in the UK
Description: The project is expected to provide a comprehensive overview of the availability of sustainable feedstocks for low carbon fuels used in the UK transport sector, such as biofuels, renewable fuels of non-biological origin and recycled carbon fuels, between now and 2050. This includes a review of different resource estimates for individual feedstocks and/or categories as well as the different factors that could impact on availability, highlighting opportunities and risks. Feedstocks associated with higher risk of land use change and other uses, such as food and feed crops, are to be considered but are considered a lower priority in view of current shares of waste-derived fuels in the UK and policies in place to promote their use further. The report will also set out what type of fuels may be produced from these feedstocks, including information on processing routes and greenhouse gas performance. Given the global nature of renewable fuels markets, the report should cover both feedstocks from domestic production and imports, differentiating clearly between the two. On imports, where possible information on the potential countries of origin should be included.
Attachments: T0277 SPaTS 2 DfT Award Letter - ARUP.docx

Title: Library Reading Lists System
Description: This tender is for a reading lists system and associated services for the University Library at the University of Hull.  The University Library forms part of the Information Services Directorate, with ICT, and operates out of the Brynmor Jones Library (BJL) and the Hull History Centre (HHC).  The University Library is responsible for the acquisition of learning resources and management and delivery of such resources as part of the Library's collections.  The collections themselves include 950,000 items, plus nearly 400,000 eBooks and 70,000 eJournals: annual loans amount to ~130,000 per annum.  The Library covers over 13,000 sq m and offers over 2,000 study spaces.  The BJL is open on a 24/7 basis.

Title: Supply of Timber for Live Fire Training - AWARD
Description:
Hampshire and Isle of Wight Fire and Rescue Service invites applications from suitably experienced organisations who wish to tender for the supply of timber for live fire training exercises for firefighters. The timber is burned to simulate the conditions experienced during various fire situations.
      
      The timber required will be formaldehyde low or free Oriented Strand Board Type 3 (OSB3) and must be cut to sizes designed to fit the training equipment prior to delivery. Delivery is required to live fire training sites in or around Hampshire including Southampton and Portsmouth, and the Isle of Wight.
      
      Further information is available in the Invitation to Tender documentation.
      
      The contract will commence on 1 January 2022 and will be for a period of 2 years with the option to extend for an additional period of up to 2 years.

Title: Plant Hire - AWARD
Description:
Title: Plant Hire
      
      Description: Sandwell MBC Highways Services are responsible for co-ordinating plant hire throughout Sandwell. Highways Services are working with the Corporate Procurement Service in order to establish a Framework Agreement for the provision of plant hire to supply a range of plant, including compressors, rollers, plate vibrators, excavators, tippers and other specialist plant to meet the plant hire requirements of Sandwell MBC (the "Council"). Highways Services wishes to invite interested suppliers ("Tenderers") to participate in a tender exercise in relation to the Framework Agreement. The plant hire contract covers a multitude of Plant and equipment for short and long term periods.  Details of which are provided in the Price Schedule.
      
      Suppliers should be working towards or be accredited with the following or equivalent; ISO 9001:2015, ISO 14001:2015, BS OHASA 18001.
      
      All plant supplied under this contract must be as specified in the Price Schedule and must be no older than 3 years old.
      
      All plant supplied under this contract must be safety checked and come under a strict maintenance regime.
      
      All plant requested must be supplied within 3 working days and shall be delivered to the specified address.
      
      All plant supplied must arrive in good working order.
      
      All plant must be delivered within normal working hours (Monday - Friday 7.00am - 3.30pm).  There may be instances where plant is required out of hours, e.g. weekend.
      
      Suppliers shall notify the Council of their fair wear and tear policy prior to the commencement of the hire of any plant items.
      
      All defective plant must be replaced within 24hours.
      
      Suppliers must provide the following Health and Safety data for any items of plant that is hired:
      
      Data sheet and operating manual 
      Hand Arm Vibration (HAVS) including trigger times.
      Noise 
      Whole Body Vibration (WBV)
      Where applicable hand tools must comply with the Control of Vibrations at Work Regulations 2005.
      
      If the Primary Supplier on any occasion cannot supply a particular piece of plant within the 3 day turnaround, or if they are underperforming, then the Council reserves the right to go to the next supplier in the list.
      The Contractor shall undertake repairs and maintenance work to tenanted properties, in order to raise the dwelling to an acceptable standard of fit and finish.
      
      Typically work will include building and renovation operations.  Trades generally required are carpenters, plumbers, bricklayers, plasterers, painters and decorators, labourer's, ground-workers, electricians and gas engineers. However, this list is not exhaustive.
      
      The Tender Document(s) will be made available to suppliers who Express Interest on the Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council Tendering Portal. To access the portal please click the following link https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sandwellmbc
      
      You will be required to log into an existing accou...

Title: Framework for the supply of Curtains and Blinds - AWARD
Description:
Hampshire County Council invites applications from suitably experienced organisations who wish to be considered for selection to tender for the Framework for the supply of Curtains and Blinds.
      
      The Framework will commence on 01 May 2022 and will be for a period of 4 years.
      
      Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire, and complete and submit the tender return document together with any supporting information requested by 14:00 hrs on Tuesday 25 January 2022.  
      
      How to obtain the Tender Documents
      The Tender documents can be accessed when logged into In-Tend by selecting 'View Details' on the relevant tender advert and clicking the 'Express Interest' tab. Once in the tender there are five tabs - 'Tender', 'ITT - documents', 'Correspondence', 'Clarifications' and 'History'. Select the 2nd tab (ITT - documents) where you will find useful information under 'Tender Details' continue to scroll down to the heading 'Tender Documents Received' where you will be able to view / download the documents.
      
      Please download all the documents and read very carefully.
      
      Opting In and Opting Out
      Please note you are required to 'Opt In' before you can access the 'My tender Return' to start populating your response. 
      
      PLEASE NOTE you are required to 'Opt In' to view & complete the Questionnaire for this project. 
      
      The 'Opt Out' functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision.
      
      You can choose to 'Opt In' at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to 'Opt Out'.
      
      Further Guidance
      In addition, guidance on how to participate in a tender - download and upload documents / returns and if required, register your company (free of charge), can be found on the In-tend site under the 'Help' or 'Information for Suppliers' buttons.

Title: NTU/21/2002/DS
Description:
Nottingham Trent University wishes to establish a multi-provider agreement for the provision of Legal Services. The University will work closely with the chosen Suppliers throughout the term of the Framework Agreement to achieve greater value for money for the University.

It is estimated that NTU spends over the framework lifespan of £3,800,000 on Legal Services and is inviting Suppliers to Tender for the provision of these services under an Agreement that will run initially for two years, up to a maximum period of four years, subject to satisfactory performance. There is no guarantee of volume or usage levels under the Agreement.

The Framework Agreement will allow qualifying firms to supply the services identified in the technical specification, on the agreed terms and for the duration of the Framework Agreement period. NTU will engage Providers by placing individual assignments/instructions under the terms of the Agreement.

The Tenderer shall be required to deliver a cost effective service that maximises value for money for NTU through the delivery of a timely, effective, up-to-date and quality service.

It is critical that the Tenderer develops an understanding of the organisational aims, tasks and risks, the working environment and culture and requirements of NTU.

The services may be ad-hoc, project-related, routine, or related to ongoing activities. Tenderers may typically be used to complement and/or supplement NTU's own in-house legal team. Project related work may require the Tenderers' personnel or nominated third party to participate as members of project teams or project boards.

The University's Human Resource department wish to appoint one Supplier (Lot 2b) to act on the basis of an agreed retention service agreement. In exchange of the monthly retainer fee, the University expects the appointed Supplier to demonstrate their added value propositions including Service Level turnarounds, staff development and access to suitable qualified lawyers in a range of disciplines.

Title: South Cambridgeshire District Council - Sports Coordinator 2021
Description:
South Cambridgeshire District Council (SCDC) is a rural area, which completely encircles Cambridge City Council area and comprises of 104 villages, 1 town and 1 developing town. Villages range from very small hamlets to more substantial settlements of 8,000 plus population. The district has 18 secondary schools, 56 primary schools and a wide range of village-based sport, recreation and community facilities.
The Council has dual use agreements that enable community access to secondary school sports facilities, which are managed directly by the schools, and also uses other outdoor sports facilities run by parish councils and local village organisations, to deliver its sports programmes. The district sits within two School Sports Partnership areas and within the Cambridgeshire and Peterborough County Sports Partnership. 
Responsibility for sports development sits within the Councils Communications and Communities team within the Transformation Service area. The service includes a small team of officers whose work includes sports and community development. For sports, the team manages a range of sport and health related initiatives as well as supporting and enabling the development and improvement of sports facilities across the district. Much of this work is done in partnership with others, including with neighbouring local authorities, parish councils, governing bodies of sport, the Primary Care Networks, schools and the above sports partnerships.

As part of this process SCDC is running a bidders days workshop on the 7/1/2022 from 2pm to 4pm to enable bidders to understand what they need to do in order to bid for this contract.  To apply for this tender and to receive the tender documentation please register on our electronic tendering portal: https://procontract.due-north.com/Advert?advertId=7a5e666b-7a61-ec11-8110-005056b64545

Title: 2944/LM - Content Delivery Support to Chinese Social Media
Description:
The University of Sheffield is seeking a Media Agency responsible for the day to day account management of our institutional Weibo and WeChat accounts, their upkeep and adherence to university branding and accessibility guidelines.

To be responsible for content development on Weibo and WeChat - designing, scheduling and sharing posts to ensure maximum effectiveness. This output should be based on our social media principles of utility, responsiveness, connection and representation, alongside with a deep understanding of our audience. 

To manage the University's reputation, the Media Agency should report on the impact of our channels and monitor mentions of the university on Weibo and WeChat to highlight potential issues affecting reputation. 

To proactively make suggestions on content, formats and process to ensure the ongoing development of our Weibo and WeChat channels. To also provide crucial consultation and insight into content approaches, audience need and issue management.

Tender Process and Documentation:
This is an Open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield
If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender, they must be submitted via the In-tend System.
Your tender response must also be submitted through InTend to arrive by the date and time specified. Late tenders will not be considered.

Closing date for receipt of bids: 11th January 2022 at 12 noon (UK time).

The BEPO decommissioning process encompasses the reactor core, bio-shield and foundations. This specification relates to design of PP&E used to decommission the reactor core only. The decommissioning process is already well defined in the Decommissioning Programme and therefore the Consultant is required to produce scheme designs for the PP&E to support the existing decommissioning process rather than develop the process itself. This process is also reflected in the Decommissioning Safety Case. The functionality of the PP&E shall meet the requirements of the Safety Case and ensure that decommissioning of the BEPO reactor core is achieved safely. The following documents shall be used as the basis and starting point for the Consultant's concept design activities: Decommissioning Programme (Ref BOSS/SC/001/13 Issue 4) Decommissioning Safety Case (Ref BEP0/DSC/17/0001 Issue 2) Level 3 Radiological Risk and ALARP Assessment (Ref BEP0/DSC/17/0001/07 Issue 1) The current status of the reactor core and bio-shield (and hence the design start point) is described in Section 4 below. The end point is for the 6m3 ILW concrete boxes to have been filled, grouted, lidded and placed onto transport in readiness for egress from the decommissioning site. The anticipated PP&E for the entire decommissioning process in described in Appendix B.

Title: Pedestrian Crossing Program
Description:
Pedestrian crossing points are key to helping pedestrians travel safely around the city and the scope of this programme is to improve pedestrian crossing facilities thus improving safety, reducing accidents, improving perception of personal safety for cyclists and pedestrians to reduce car dependency and usage, encouraging more active lifestyles particularly for shorter journeys.  

Brighton & Hove City Council's (BHCC) Transport Projects & Engineering (TP&E) Team collates and assesses requests received for new or improved pedestrian crossings from both members of the public and local Ward Members each financial year.  For locations that meet the pre-assessment criteria a wide-ranging assessment is carried out and the location is assigned a priority score.  The locations are then ranked by their priority score (highest to lowest) and informs the Pedestrian Crossing Priority List.

Those crossing locations achieving a ranking within the top 10 will be prioritised for funding but this does not automatically qualify a particular location for implementation.  For example, the cost of a crossing facility at a particular location may be prohibitive or upon closer investigation it may become apparent that suitable pedestrian provision already exists in a particular location and therefore further investment would not represent good value for money.

The 'type' of crossing facility proposed is considered on a case-by-case basis by Highway Engineers. Often the most appropriate and cost-effective solution for locations can be pedestrian refuges or buildouts. Where larger scale facilities which are likely to exceed available budgets are required, such as full junction redesigns, schemes may be delayed until funding can be made available.
